Bleomycin¬†is an anticancer antibiotic used for the treatment of squamous cell cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma. It chelates copper or iron and produces superoxide ions that damage DNA. Side effects are mucocutaneous toxicity and¬†pulmonary fibrosis.

Doxorubicin is an¬†anthracycline¬†that is widely used in clinical practice as a chemotherapeutic agent. It is most commonly used as a part of regimens with other agents like cyclophosphamide, cisplatin, and 5-FU in several malignancies including:¬†

  • Soft-tissue sarcoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • ALL
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Hodgkin's and Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma

Cardiotoxicity¬†is a known side-effect of doxorubicin. Therefore, careful monitoring is required for doxorubicin. Specifically, doxorubicin requires dose adjustment during or after radiotherapy in order to prevent radiation toxicity.

Vincristine¬†is a vinca alkaloid that acts during the¬†M phase¬†of the cell cycle. It causes microtubule disruptions, thereby preventing cellular replication.¬†Side effects are neuropathy¬†and SIADH.

Capecitabine¬†is a¬†pyrimidine analog¬†that is classified as an¬†antimetabolite agent. Side effects are diarrhea, hand-foot syndrome, and myelosuppression.

questions.text: A young patient presented with symptoms of bronchial asthma and cromolyn sodium was prescribed. It should be administered by which of the following routes?
questions.solution:

Sodium cromoglycate is a mast cell stabilizer, which inhibits the degranulation of mast cells and restricts the release of inflammatory cytokines. It prevents bronchoconstriction but does not act as a direct bronchodilator and hence cannot be used once bronchoconstriction is established or during an asthmatic attack.¬†

It is not absorbed orally. It is administered through the inhalation route for the treatment of bronchial asthma. It can also be used in the treatment of allergic conjunctivitis as a topical application.

The therapeutic benefit develops slowly over 2-4 weeks and lasts 1- 2 weeks after discontinuation of the drug. Its use has declined due to the widespread usage of inhaled corticosteroids.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman who did not respond well to metformin therapy was started on dapagliflozin. Which of the following is not true about this drug?

SGLT2 - Sodium-glucose cotransporter - 2

choices.text: It increases risk of urinary tract infections
It acts by inhibiting SGLT-2 transporter on distal convoluted tubule
It increases the risk of fractures

questions.solution:
Dapagliflozin acts by inhibiting the SGLT2 transporter present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. SGLT2 transporter is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and not in the distal convoluted tubule.

The SGLT2 transporter present in the proximal segment of the renal tubule is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. Dapagliflozin acts by inhibiting this transporter resulting in glycosuria and decreasing the blood glucose level. This drug is effective orally. This drug also results in weight loss.

Dapagliflozin has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of heart failure in both diabetic and non-diabetic patients.

The common side effects of dapagliflozin include urinary tract infections, genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine, and also increased¬†risk of fractures.

Other SGLT2 inhibitors include empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and ertugliflozin.

Empagliflozin has been found to decrease the risk of mortality from cardiovascular causes in diabetic patients.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman came to the hospital with complaints of excruciating paroxysmal pain on the right side of her lips, gums, and cheek. Carbamazepine acts by¬†slowing¬†the recovery rate of voltage-activated sodium channels from their inactivated state¬†and acts as a sodium channel blocker.¬†

It is used as the primary drug in both trigeminal and glossopharyngeal neuralgias. It is also the primary agent for treating generalized tonic-clonic and focal seizures. It can also be used in bipolar affective disorders.

Carbamazepine also has a potentiating effect on the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in¬†water retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease. Other adverse effects include:

  • Hypersensitivity reactions¬†such as:
    • Stevens-Johnson syndrome

    • Hepatotoxicity (on concomitant use with valproate)
  • Dose-related neurotoxicity such as:

questions.text: A patient with endometrial cancer comes with pain in her right calf which is confirmed to be a thrombus by USG. Which of the following is preferred to be used in her to prevent propagation of the clot and why?

choices.text: Low molecular weight heparin, short half life
Low molecular weight heparin, more bioavailability

questions.solution:
The anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism is low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). It is the preferred agent because of more bioavailability, lack of need for anticoagulant monitoring, and a long t1/2.¬†

Venous thromboembolism (including deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and splanchnic vein thrombosis), is a frequent complication of cancer and is the second-leading cause of death in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.

Based on the results from the¬†Comparison of Low-molecular-weight¬†heparin vs.¬†Oral anticoagulants for long-term anticoagulation in cancer patients with venous Thromboembolism (CLOT) Trial, all recent guidelines now advise LMWH for cancer-associated thromboembolism.¬†

However, unfractionated heparin (UFH) can be used in patients with renal failure, and fondaparinux can be considered in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

Tinzaparin (LMWH) is used for maintenance treatment in patients with cancer-associated venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: Tacrine and malathion inhibit the Acetylcholine esterase enzyme by binding to which of the following site/sites?
questions.solution:
Tacrine binds to the anionic site and malathion binds to the esteratic site of the Acetylcholine esterase enzyme and inhibits it.

Anticholinesterase drugs:

Reversible inhibitors

Carbamates Non-Carbamates
Physostigmine, Neostigmine, Pyridostigmine, Rivastigmine Edrophonium, Tacrine, Donepezil, Galantamine


Irreversible inhibitors

Carbamates Organophosphates
Carbaryl, Propoxur Dyflos, Echthiophate, Malathion, Diazinon, Tabun, Sarin, Soman


The AChE has two sites, an anionic site, and an esteratic site. Edrophonium and tacrine (Non-Carbamates) attach only to the anionic site and do not form covalent bonds with the enzyme. In contrast, organophosphates attach only to the esteratic site forming strong covalent bonds. Carbamates bind to both anionic and esteratic sites.

Reactivation of edrophonium¬≠ inhibited enzyme occurs in < 10 min, because the interaction is by forming weak hydrogen bonds, and does not involve hydrolysis of the inhibitor, but only its diffusion. The reactivation of carbamylated enzyme (1/2 to 6 hours) is less than that of the synthesis of fresh enzyme protein. In contrast, that of the phosphorylated enzyme (in days) is more than the regeneration time. The phosphorylated enzyme may also undergo ‚Äòageing‚Äô by the loss of one of the alkyl groups and become resistant to hydrolysis.

questions.text:
An HIV-positive patient diagnosed with CMV retinitis was initiated on ganciclovir. Which ART drug among the following should be avoided?

ART-Anti Retroviral Therapy
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, zidovudine has to be avoided. Ganciclovir used to treat CMV retinitis is associated with the risk of bone marrow suppression, leading to anaemia and neutropenia. Zidovudine, an antiretroviral drug, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor, is also known to cause bone marrow suppression and can exacerbate these hematologic side effects when used with ganciclovir. Hence zidovudine has to be avoided in patients receiving ganciclovir to prevent enhanced bone marrow suppression.

Other options

Option B: Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor that does not have significant bone marrow toxicity. Hence, it can be given along with ganciclovir.

Option C: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor that is safe for patients receiving ganciclovir.

Option D: Dolutegravir, an integrase inhibitor, is safe for patients receiving ganciclovir and does not have bone marrow side effects.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was taken to the emergency department with palpitations and restlessness after using a salbutamol inhaler 15 times in one hour following an asthma attack. Her chest examination was clear on auscultation, and cardiac examination showed tachycardia with a regular rhythm, without murmurs. What features are likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol toxicity can cause muscle tremors due to stimulation of¬†Œ≤2-adrenergic receptors in skeletal muscle. It is the most common side effect. The risk is higher with elderly patients and those with COPD.

Salbutamol is a relatively selective Œ≤2- adrenergic receptor agonist.¬†In overdose, receptor specificity may be lost and stimulation of cardiac Œ≤2-receptors may cause tachycardia, cardiac ischemia, and arrhythmias. It causes hypokalemia¬†(option C)¬†by stimulating Œ≤2-receptors of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump in the skeletal muscle, shifting K+ intracellularly. This can produce ECG changes such as flattening and inversion of T waves (option A), QT prolongation, and U waves.¬†

Acute salbutamol toxicity may cause lactic acidosis. Œ≤2-adrenergic stimulation increases gluconeogenesis and lipolysis. This causes increased plasma glucose, leading to increased conversion of pyruvate and lactate. Overdose can result in hyperglycemia (option B), lactic acidosis, and cardiac arrhythmias.¬†

Other adverse effects include hypoxemia and metabolic effects such as an increase in free fatty acids and¬†insulin. Desensitization is noted in the long-term use of salbutamol.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presented with difficulty in urination and back pain. His PSA levels were found to be elevated and the x-ray pelvis revealed two osteoblastic lesions in the bony pelvis. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat the given condition?

PSA - Prostate Specific Antigen
questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigations showing elevated PSA osteoblastic lesions in the pelvis are suggestive of metastatic¬†prostate cancer. Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist used in the treatment of prostate cancer.

Androgen deprivation therapy is the primary medical therapy for prostate cancer. The drugs used for this indication are¬†GnRH agonists such as goserelin, buserelin, leuprolide, nafarelin, and triptorelin.¬†The agonist action of the GnRH analogs causes an initial increase in LH, leading to increased testosterone production. This causes a tumor flare. This can be prevented by concomitant administration of an androgen receptor antagonist¬†such as flutamide or bicalutamide.

After the initial period, there is a downregulation of GnRH receptors and changes in the downstream pathways, leading to a decrease in gonadotropins and testosterone (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism).¬†The androgen deprivation therapy with continuous GnRH agonist and an androgen receptor antagonist is as effective as surgical castration in reducing the levels of serum testosterone.

GnRH antagonists such as degarelix can also be used for androgen deprivation therapy. It has the advantage of not having a tumor flare phenomenon. However, because of the long-term safety profile of GnRH agonists, they are the preferred drugs for androgen deprivation therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor¬†used in the treatment of advanced breast cancer.

Option B:¬†Desogestrel is a synthetic progestin without androgenic activity. It is used in combination with ethinyl estradiol for oral contraception.

Option D: Spironolactone¬†is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is a weak inhibitor of the androgen receptor and causes gynecomastia as a common side effect. It has been used in women to treat hirsutism.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is representative of the graph as given below?
questions.solution:
The graph represents the time-dependent killing and is demonstrated by penicillin (Beta-lactam antibiotics) and macrolides.¬†

In antimicrobial pharmacodynamics, antibiotics are generally categorised based on how their antimicrobial action depends on time or concentration. ¬†

1. Time-dependent killing: These antibiotics rely on the amount of time the drug concentration remains above the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) to exert their effect. Once the concentration is above the MIC, increasing the concentration further does not significantly increase the rate of bacterial killing. Instead, the duration of exposure is key to effective bacterial eradication. This type is typically seen in beta-lactam antibiotics.¬†

Penicillins, cephalosporins, and vancomycin are examples of medications that demonstrate time-dependent killing. For these drugs, multiple daily doses are preferred over single doses.

The image below shows time-dependent killing.

2. Concentration-dependent killing: These antibiotics rely on achieving high peak concentrations to maximize bacterial killing. The higher the peak concentration relative to the MIC, the more effective the drug is. This means that the maximum concentration (Cmax) is more critical for efficacy. This type is seen in aminoglycosides (e.g., amikacin, gentamicin) and fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin). ¬†

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is seen over multiple visits for complaints of gastric ulcers despite the use of ranitidine. Further evaluation revealed elevated levels of gastrin and evidence of ulcers involving the jejunum suggesting a diagnosis of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Which of the following agents would be most useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Lansoprazole¬†is the most useful in the management of this patient.

Lansoprazole is an H1/K1-ATPase proton pump inhibitor useful in the treatment of patients who have failed histamine H2-blocker therapy and patients with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

Patients with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome develop pancreatic or duodenal gastrinomas that stimulate the secretion of very large amounts of acid, sometimes in the setting of multiple endocrine neoplasia, type I.¬†This can lead to severe gastroduodenal ulceration and other consequences of uncontrolled hyperchlorhydria.

Proton pump inhibitors¬†are activated by the proton-catalyzed formation of a tetracyclic sulfenamide. This leads to the trapping of the drug so that it does not diffuse back across the canalicular membrane. The activated compound forms a covalent bond with sulfhydryl groups of cysteines in the H+/K+¬†ATPase irreversibly, thus inactivating the pump molecule. They primarily promote healing of gastric and duodenal ulcers and is used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease, including erosive esophagitis, that is complicated or unresponsive to treatment with H2 receptor antagonists. They are used along with antibiotics for the eradication of Helicobacter pylori. They are used as the mainstay treatment of pathological hypersecretory conditions, including the Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

Other options:

Option A- Famotidine is a histamine H2-blocker.

Option C- Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analogue used to prevent ulcers in patients taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Option D- Propantheline is a quaternary ammonium anticholinergic agent which inhibits the muscarinic actions of acetylcholine on autonomic nerve endings. Propantheline were being used to alleviate symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome, painful gastrointestinal motility disorders and peptic ulcer disease. It has been replaced by more effective antiulcer agents.¬†

questions.text: A patient with peptic ulcer disease was prescribed ranitidine and sucralfate. The combination is incorrect because

choices.text: Sucralfate interferes with absorption of ranitidine
Combination produces serious adverse effect like agranulocytosis
Ranitidine combines with sucralfate and interferes with its absorption
Ranitidine increases gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act

questions.solution:
Ranitidine increases gastric pH and hence sucralfate is not able to polymerize as it requires an acidic pH to form a protective layer over the ulcer. Hence it is not a rational combination.

Sucralfate, in an acidic environment (pH < 4) acts by producing a viscous, sticky polymer that adheres to ulcer craters and epithelial cells for up to 6 hours after a single dose. This viscous layer produced in the stomach leads to the inhibition of absorption of other drugs, like phenytoin, digoxin, cimetidine, ketoconazole, and fluoroquinolone antibiotics.¬†

Constipation is the most common side effect of sucralfate. It should be avoided in patients with renal failure who are at risk of aluminium overload. Aluminium-containing antacids should not be combined with sucralfate in these patients. ¬†As the viscous gel produced by sucralfate is sticky, it may eventually lead to bezoar formation.

It is generally used for prophylaxis of peptic ulcers, but rarely so because its side effects and its risks outweigh its benefits.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient has been prescribed a drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of his chronic gout. What is this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of chronic gout is pegloticase.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase) that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite.¬†It is used in the treatment of severe,¬†refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated. The efficacy of this drug gets lowered if antibodies are produced against the drug, which occurs in many patients. This also increases the risk of infusion reactions.¬†

Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase. It is indicated for the initial management of elevated plasma uric acid levels in patients with malignancies who are on chemotherapy. The efficacy is limited by the production of antibodies to the drug.

Gout occurs due to the precipitation of urate crystals in the tissues with a subsequent inflammatory response. In an acute episode of gout, there is painful distal monoarthritis which can lead to joint destruction, subcutaneous tophi, and renal calculi. Management of gout includes:

  • Reduction of pain and inflammation: NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids
  • Inhibition of the formation of urate: Allopurinol, febuxostat
  • Promotion of urate excretion: Probenecid, lesinurad

Other options:¬†

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils. Overall reducing the inflammatory response.

Option B:¬†Febuxostat is a¬†xanthine oxidase inhibitor approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

On blood investigations, it was found that she had increased T3 and T4 levels and decreased TSH levels.  Which of the following should be the next step in the management of this patient?

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with gastroparesis. Which of the following drugs cannot be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Gastroparesis can be treated with prokinetic agents such as metoclopramide, cisapride, and motilin. Loperamide is an orally active antimotility and antisecretory agent¬†and cannot be used to treat gastroparesis.

Loperamide acts by increasing the mouth to the caecum and small intestine transit times and increases the tone of the anal sphincter.

Prokinetic agents enhance coordinated GI motility and the transit of material in the GI tract. They do not interfere with the normal physiological pattern and rhythm of motility. They act through the following mechanisms of action:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonists: Metoclopramide and domperidone
  • Serotonin receptor agonists: cisapride and prucalopride
  • Mimicking motilin action: Erythromycin and other macrolide antibiotics

Indications for use of prokinetic agents such as metoclopramide include gastroparesis, in medical or diagnostic procedures such as upper endoscopy or contrast radiography of the GI tract and ameliorate nausea and vomiting that often accompany GI dysmotility syndromes.

questions.text: Oral digoxin is being given to a 65-year-old male patient with congestive heart failure as a maintenance dose to gradually digitalize him. A target plasma concentration of 0.70 ng/mL is decided upon. The digoxin clearance for this particular individual is calculated as 60 mL/min. Knowing that the oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70%, what is the dosing rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The dosing rate in this patient is¬†60 ng/min.

The oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70% (F = 0.7) and the required target plasma concentration (Cp) is 0.70 ng/mL. CL is the clearance of digoxin which is¬†60 mL/min.

Hence, the appropriate dose rate for this patient can be calculated as:

Dosing rate = Target Cp x CL/F

= [0.70 ng/mL √ó 60 mL/min] √∑ [0.7]

= 60 ng/min

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being treated with oral antidiabetic drugs. She has a history of hypothyroidism and is on levothyroxine therapy. Routine blood tests reveal low TSH levels and normal free T4 and T3 levels. Which of the following drugs may be responsible for this patient's blood test results?
questions.solution:
Metformin is the most likely cause of low TSH levels and normal free T4 and T3 levels in this patient.

Metformin belongs to the biguanide class of oral hypoglycemic drugs. Metformin is accepted as the first-line treatment of type 2 diabetes and is the most commonly used oral agent for this condition. It acts primarily by inhibiting hepatic gluconeogenesis. It activates AMP-dependent protein kinase, leading to stimulation of hepatic fatty acid oxidation, glucose uptake, and nonoxidative glucose metabolism and reduction of lipogenesis and gluconeogenesis.

Metformin is associated with decreased TSH levels. It also prevents an increase in the thyroid volume.

Other options:

Option B: Dapagliflozin, a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor, is not known to affect thyroid function.

Option C: Sitagliptin, a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor, has no significant effects on thyroid function.

Option D: Glibenclamide, a sulfonylurea, also does not impact thyroid function.

A 17-year-old girl was admitted with a large wound on her thigh for the past 3 months. Cultures from the wound margin revealed an MRSA infection. She was given an antibiotic that binds to the subunit of the ribosome marked by the red cross and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. Identify the drug given to this patient.

questions.solution:
The drug given in this case is¬†Linezolid¬†which binds to the¬†P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit¬†and¬†inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an¬†oxazolidinone¬†that¬†is active against various resistant organisms including methicillin-resistant staphylococci, vancomycin-resistant staphylococci.¬†Linezolid is well absorbed orally and the¬†bioavailability approaches 100%.

Linezolid and tedizolid are FDA approved for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections caused by streptococci and staphylococcus aureus (MSSA and MRSA).¬†Linezolid is also approved for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to S. pneumoniae and nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus.

Adverse efffects of linezolid:

  • Myelosuppression¬†(anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia)
  • Thrombocytopenia¬†(most common side effect)¬†
  • Serotonin syndrome if given along with serotonergic drugs due to monoamine oxidase¬†(MAO) inhibition
  • Mitochondrial toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuropathy, lactic acidosis

This prevents the peptide bond formation by breaking the interaction between peptidyl transferase and its amino acid substrate. One of the most important adverse effects of chloramphenicol is¬†grey baby syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with chronic angina was prescribed a new drug, ranolazine. This drug acts by which of the following mechanism?

choices.text: Inhibit funny currents in SA node

questions.solution:
Ranolazine acts by¬†late sodium current¬†inhibition¬†in the heart.¬†It is used in the prophylaxis of angina.

Late sodium current (INa) facilitates the entry of calcium via the sodium-calcium exchanger. Inhibition of¬†INa, therefore, reduces the intracellular calcium concentration which in turn reduces the diastolic tension and cardiac contractility.

At higher doses, it may also modify the fatty acid oxidation (pFOX inhibitor), which improves the efficiency of cardiac oxygen utilisation but whether this actually occurs at therapeutic doses is still being studied. It also has mild beta-blocking activity.

Ranolazine is the second-line FDA-approved drug for heart failure. Side effects of ranolazine include dizziness, headache, and postural hypotension.

Other options:

Option A:¬†Ivabradine selectively blocks the funny current (If) channel¬†involved in the generation of automaticity in the SA node. It reduces heart rate and thereby oxygen demand. It does not have any effect on cardiac contractility. It is an FDA-approved drug for the treatment of heart failure. It is also used for treating stable angina.

Option C:¬†Fasudil¬†acts by inhibiting smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm.

Option D:¬†Nicorandil acts as an agonist at ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP) channels i.e. potassium channel opener. It decreases afterload and preload of the heart by its vasodilatory properties at both arterioles and venules. It is used for the treatment of stable angina.

Note: Trimetazidine is a¬†pFOX inhibitor¬†that partially inhibits fatty acid oxidation in the myocardium. Thereby, it decreases the oxygen requirement. It is also used as an anti-anginal agent.

  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels

    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand

    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist

questions.text: Which of the following drugs act by reversible inhibition of P2Y12 receptor?
questions.solution:
Ticagrelor is a reversible inhibitor¬†of P2Y12 receptor.

Injury to the vessel wall exposes the subendothelial collagen and causes platelets to adhere and activate at the site. Activated platelets release ADP, which binds to P2Y12 receptors on other platelets in the circulation and causes their activation. This can cause amplifying cycles of clot formation and complete occlusion of the blood vessels. This is especially dangerous in patients with atherosclerotic plaques in the coronary arteries. Any acute plaque change, such as ulceration, can lead to thrombosis and acute coronary syndromes.¬†

This is where anti-platelet drugs such as P2Y12 inhibitors come in. P2Y12 inhibitors include clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor and cangrelor. Some of the features of these drugs are summarized below:

Clopidogrel Irreversible P2Y12 antagonist, oral

It is a prodrug; that requires activation by CYP 2C19 to work.

Blocks platelet aggregation for the entire lifetime of platelets

PPIs such as omeprazole and pantoprazole inhibit CYP 2C19, thus reducing the formation of the active metabolite of clopidogrel and leading to therapeutic failure.
Prasugrel Irreversible P2Y12 antagonist, oral It has a more rapid onset of action compared to clopidogrel.
Ticagrelor Reversible P2Y12 antagonist, oral

More rapid onset and offset of action compared to clopidogrel.

Associated with dyspnea and higher risk of intracranial bleeding; contraindicated in patients with a history of intracranial bleeding.
Cangrelor Reversible P2Y12 antagonist, intravenous The action begins within minutes and lasts for one hour following the stoppage of the drug.

Dextromethorphan¬†is a centrally-acting NMDA¬†receptor antagonist that is used as an antitussive.

The antitussive action of dextromethorphan is due to the d-isomer, whereas the l-isomer is an analgesic.

questions.text: Which of the following nomograms is used for paracetamol poisoning ?
questions.solution:
Rumack Matthew nomogram is used in paracetamol poisoning. In this nomogram serum acetaminophen concentration is measured for the time after ingestion which is useful in assessing potential hepatotoxicity after an acute ingestion of paracetamol.

Acetaminophen toxicity clinically presents with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Later, renal failure and myocardial injury may be seen. Low bilirubin levels along with raised aminotransferase levels are characteristic of the condition.¬†

Acetaminophen toxicity is an important cause of acute liver failure. Ingestion of ‚â•25g can be fatal. Cytochrome P450 CYP2E1 metabolizes acetaminophen to N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI). Glutathione is responsible for its detoxification, after which it is excreted in the urine. When glutathione reserves are depleted or large amounts of NAPQI are formed, it binds to hepatocyte macromolecules. This can then lead to hepatocyte necrosis.

Initial management includes gastric lavage and oral charcoal or cholestyramine. It should be carried out within thirty minutes of ingestion. If they are used, gastric lavage must be done afterwards before using another agent. Acetaminophen blood levels can be estimated from a nomogram plot. In patients with high acetaminophen levels, intravenous N-acetylcysteine administration within 8 hours of ingestion is recommended. It helps in the replenishment of glutathione. It is partially effective even up to 36 hours. Liver transplantation is necessary if signs of hepatic failure continue despite therapy.¬†

Other option(s):

questions.text:
The following finding was seen on performing a DAT scan in a patient who presented with bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremors. Which of the following drugs could be used in the treatment of this condition?

DAT - Dopamine active transporter
questions.solution:
The¬†DAT(Dopamine active transporter)scan image shows a normal¬†comma-shaped¬†pattern of the striatal nuclei, which rules out degenerative parkinsonism, suggesting secondary parkinsonism such as¬†drug-induced¬†parkinsonism. Among the given options,¬†Benztropine¬†can be used for¬†drug-induced parkinsonism and it is an anticholinergic.

Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition caused by certain drugs having D2 antagonistic action (typical antipsychotics). The decrease in dopaminergic activity results in an¬†unbalanced cholinergic activity. Anticholinergics act by restoring balance.

Management of Drug-induced Parkinsonism

There are two approaches to managing drug-induced parkinsonism: avoidance or discontinuation of known causative medications and symptomatic treatment of parkinsonism.

  1. Avoidance or discontinuation of the drug- The best way to treat drug-induced parkinsonism is to avoid using causative agents, especially in high-risk populations such as older adults. Unfortunately, this is not always possible, as some patients with psychosis need to be treated with antipsychotic agents.
  2. Symptomatic treatment-¬†When the causative agent cannot be discontinued, lowered, or switched to an alternative drug, symptomatic treatment of parkinsonism may be considered like:
  • Anticholinergic -¬†Benztropine
  • Amantadine
  • Levodopa

DAT (Dopamine transporter)¬†is a presynaptic transporter that transmits the dopamine from the synaptic cleft, back into the presynaptic nerve terminal. The¬†DATscan¬†is an imaging technique that uses¬†ioflupane¬†iodine-123¬†injection, a contrast agent that is taken up by the DATs in the presynaptic neurons in the striatal nuclei. questions.text: A 66-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss and anorexia. On examination, generalised lymphadenopathy is seen. Peripheral smear showed smudge cells and increased lymphocytes. Which of the following antimetabolites is preferred in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of fatigue, weight loss, anorexia, generalized lymphadenopathy, and the presence of smudge cells on a peripheral smear suggest chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL). Smudge cells are characteristic of CLL. The preferred antimetabolite in this case is Fludarabine.

Fludarabine is a purine analogue and an antimetabolite commonly used in the treatment of CLL. It acts by inhibiting DNA synthesis in rapidly dividing cells, including malignant lymphocytes. It is the preferred choice in this scenario for managing CLL.

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) is associated with the deletions of 13q, 11q, 17q, and trisomy 12q. Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes with proliferation centres. The peripheral smear shows small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and smudge cells as seen below.

Expectant management is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The gold standard for therapy is a combination of fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab.

Other options:

Option A: 5-Fluorouracil (5FU) is a thymidylate synthase inhibitor. It is used in treating breast, colon, oesophagal, stomach and anal cancer. It is used in the FOLFOX or FOLFIRINOX combination to treat pancreatic or colorectal cancer. It is combined with cisplatin in head and neck cancer. It is also used in treating premalignant skin lesions (topical). 5-FU is not typically used in the treatment of CLL.

Option C: 6-Mercaptopurine inhibits purine nucleotide synthesis and metabolism. It is used in the treatment of acute lymphocytic and myelogenous leukaemia, small cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, Crohn‚Äôs disease and ulcerative colitis.¬† 6-Mercaptopurine is not typically used in the treatment of CLL.

Option D: Azathioprine is a purine antimetabolite. It is an imidazolyl derivative of 6-mercaptopurine, metabolites of which can inhibit purine synthesis. Azathioprine is indicated as an adjunct for the prevention of organ transplant rejection and in severe rheumatoid arthritis.¬† Azathioprine is not typically used in the treatment of CLL.

questions.text:
Which of the following forms of iron may be preferred in a patient with CKD already being treated with darbepoietin?

CKD - Chronic Kidney Disease
questions.solution:
The preferred form of iron in a patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD) already being treated with darbepoetin is intravenous iron sucrose.

Patients with CKD, particularly those receiving erythropoiesis-stimulating agents like darbepoetin, often have impaired gastrointestinal absorption of iron and increased iron requirements. Intravenous iron, such as iron sucrose, is preferred because it bypasses the gastrointestinal tract, has better bioavailability, and replenishes iron stores more efficiently in CKD patients.

Oral iron, like ferrous sulfate, is generally less effective in CKD patients, and subcutaneous or intramuscular forms, like iron dextran, are less commonly used due to risks of adverse reactions and poor absorption.

questions.text: If a drug follows first-order kinetics, how much drug will remain at the end of 6 hours when a patient is given 300 mg drug of which 120 mg is excreted in 90 min?
questions.solution:
The amount of drug remaining in the body after 6 hours following an initial administration of 300mg of the drug is 38mg.

In first-order kinetics,¬†a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time.¬†

120 mg of 300 mg is excreted in 90 minutes ---> 120/300 =¬†0.40¬†is eliminated¬†

After 90 minutes; 300 mg-120 mg = 180 mg remains¬†

The next 90 minutes (after 180 minutes) = 180 *¬†0.4 = 72 mg is eliminated and 180-72 = 108 mg remains¬†

The next 90 minutes (after 270 minutes) = 108 *¬†0.4 = 43.2 mg is eliminated and 108-43.2 = 64.8 remains¬†

The next 90 minutes (after 360 minutes) = 64.8 *¬†0.4 = 25.92 mg is eliminated and 64.80-25.92 =¬†38.88 mg remains after 6 hours.¬†

A simpler way to calculate¬†

  • 2/5 fraction is excreted in 90 minutes¬†‚Üí 3/5 remains after 90 minutes.
  • 6 hours (360 min) is 4 times of 90 minutes.
  • So 300 * (3/5)(3/5)(3/5)(3/5) = 38.88 mg remains after 360 minutes¬†

questions.text: A young man is diagnosed with hypertension. His laboratory studies reveal hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. He says that his mother was also diagnosed with hypertension at a younger age. Genetic testing revealed the presence of a mutation in ENaC gene. Which of the following drugs is commonly used in the treatment of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical, laboratory, and genetic features are suggestive of Liddle's syndrome. It occurs due to the increased function of epithelial sodium channels. Amiloride blocks these channels and is therefore commonly used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome.

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks epithelial sodium channels in collecting tubules. Therefore, it reduces sodium retention and potassium wasting.¬†Triamterene acts similar to amiloride. However, it is less potent and more toxic than amiloride.

It is used to treat Liddle's syndrome, hypokalemia due to other diuretics, and lithium-induced polyuria. Its toxicity can cause hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis.

Liddle's syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that is caused due to the gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene which codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. Due to increased sodium retention, patients present with hypertension and hypokalemic alkalosis. They have¬†normal aldosterone levels. They respond to treatment with amiloride.

Other options:

Option A:¬†Furosemide is a loop diuretic and acts by inhibiting¬†Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Therefore it is not used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome. A condition that mimics overdose loop diuretic is Bartter's syndrome. This syndrome occurs due to a defect in the¬†Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Patients will have¬†low blood pressure, polyuria, polydipsia, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, and normal to increased calcium excretion.¬†

Option B: Spironolactone¬†is an aldosterone antagonist. Since the levels of aldosterone are normal in Liddle's syndrome, it cannot be used in the treatment of the condition. The toxicity of spironolactone can cause hyperkalemia and gynecomastia.

Option D: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic and acts by the inhibition of the Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule.¬†Therefore it is not commonly used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome.¬†A condition that mimics an overdose of thiazide diuretics is Gitelman syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disease that causes a defect in the¬†Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule.¬†Patients present with low blood pressure, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalciuria.

questions.text: A patient who has undergone renal transplantation is started on mycophenolate mofetil as prophylaxis for transplant rejection. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of mycophenolate mofetil is the inhibition of inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase.

Mycophenolate mofetil is a prodrug that is rapidly converted to mycophenolic acid. It is a selective, non-competitive, reversible inhibitor of inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), an important enzyme in the de novo pathway of guanine nucleotide synthesis in T and B lymphocytes. Cyclosporine is an immunomodulatory drug that inhibits calcineurin activity by forming a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein in target cells, forming a cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex. Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor that blocks FKBP 12. This immunophilin ultimately inhibits calcineurin phosphatase and exerts its actions.¬†

Option B: Sirolimus is an antimetabolic and antiproliferative drug. It acts by forming a complex with an immunophilin called FKBP-12, inhibiting the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR). mTOR is a protein kinase that blocks cell cycle progression at the G1 phase to S phase transition. questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of familial hypercholesterolemia was prescribed alirocumab. It helps in lowering lipid by __________.
questions.solution:
Alirocumab helps in lowering lipids by PCSK-9 inhibition.

It is a monoclonal antibody that binds to proprotein convertase subtilisin Kexin type 9 (PCSK-9). PCSK-9 is a protease involved in the degradation of LDL receptors, which results in higher plasma LDL concentrations. Alirocumab binds to free PCSK-9, thereby interfering with its binding to the LDL receptor, leading to increased liver clearance of LDL from the circulation and lower serum LDL levels.

Alirocumab and evolocumab are 2 FDA-approved PCSK9 inhibitors. It is used as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, in whom the maximum tolerated statin dose is not able to achieve target LDL reduction.

It is administered as subcutaneous injections every 2 weeks or once monthly depending on the indication.

The correct option is option C i.e. the urine will have increased levels of chloride, magnesium, and potassium and decreased levels of urea.¬†

Indapamide is a thiazide diuretic that can cause increased loss of chloride, potassium, and magnesium and decreased excretion of urea in urine. Thus resulting in hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypercalcemia¬†as adverse effects.

Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter in the DCT. This results in the loss of sodium, chloride, and water contributing to the diuretic effect.

The diuretic effect of thiazide leads to decreased osmotic pressure due to the loss of Na+, Cl-, and water leading to compensatory reabsorption of uric acid thus resulting in hyperuricemia.

The intracytoplasmic Na+ concentration also decreases due to the blockade of the co-transporter. To compensate, the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger pumps sodium from the systemic circulation into the epithelial cells in exchange for calcium. The declining calcium levels inside the cell will draw more calcium from the lumen into the systemic circulation. This results in hypercalcemia. There is also increased loss of Mg2+, K+, and H+.

Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension.

The advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost
  • Effectiveness in isolated systolic hypertension

Thiazides are ineffective both as antihypertensive and diuretic in patients with chronic renal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding chlorpheniramine?

choices.text: It does not cross the blood-brain barrier

questions.solution:
Chlorpheniramine crosses the blood-brain barrier. Hence, option B is incorrect.

Chlorpheniramine is a first-generation antihistamine. First-generation antihistamines are lipophilic and hence are sedative because of their ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. It also has anticholinergic action, which can cause side effects like dry mouth and blurred vision.¬†

First-generation antihistamines such as chlorpheniramine, promethazine, dimenhydrinate diphenhydramine, cyclizine, and meclizine are effective in controlling nausea and vomiting in motion sickness. First-generation antihistamines have a strong sedative property and also have an antimuscarinic function. Whereas second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine and fexofenadine are ineffective in the treatment of motion sickness. Second-generation antihistamines are less sedative because of less central nervous system penetration and do not block autonomic receptors.
